verses.text: Man, born of woman, is short-lived and full of trouble.
verses.comment: Job opens by noting the brevity and suffering of human life, highlighting human dependence on God and the reality of original sin—echoed in Psalm 90:10 and Job 7:1. This introduces the theme of mortality and spiritual struggle central to Christian understanding.

verses.text: He comes forth like a flower and withers; he flees like a shadow and does not endure.
verses.comment: The image of humans as fading flowers and fleeting shadows is repeated in Psalms and Isaiah, emphasizing the temporary nature of earthly life and the need for divine grace—pointing spiritually to resurrection hope.

verses.text: Do you open your eyes on such a one, and bring me into judgment with you?
verses.comment: Job questions why God pays such attention to frail humans, echoing Psalm 143:2, which acknowledges that none are righteous before God. This points to the necessity of grace and mercy for salvation.

verses.text: Who can bring something clean out of the unclean? No one.
verses.comment: This asserts the doctrine of human inherited sinfulness—see Psalm 51:5 and Romans 5:12. Only through divine intervention can purification come, anticipating the sacramental means of grace.

verses.text: Since his days are determined, and the number of his months is with you, and you have set his limits so he cannot go beyond them,
verses.comment: Job here reflects God's sovereignty over human life—our days are divinely set. Echoed in Psalm 139:16, this verse encourages trust in God's providence and plan.

verses.text: Look away from him so that he may rest, till he completes his day like a hired worker.
verses.comment: Job pleads for relief from suffering, desiring freedom from hardship like a laborer finishing his work. This foreshadows the Christian teaching of rest in God after life’s work.

verses.text: For there is hope for a tree: if it is cut down, it will sprout again, and its shoots will not cease.
verses.comment: Unlike man, a tree may revive after being cut down, offering an image of renewal. The tree’s hope echoes prophetic signs of new life and restoration, as in Isaiah 11:1—a messianic foreshadowing.

verses.text: Though its root grows old in the earth and its stump dies in the ground,
verses.comment: Even when the tree seems dead, hope remains for revival. This subtly parallels the spiritual principle that even apparent spiritual death can turn to life through God’s grace.

verses.text: at the scent of water it will bud and put forth branches like a young plant.
verses.comment: Water symbolizes life and renewal, recalling Psalm 1:3, where the righteous are likened to trees by streams of water. In spiritual interpretation, water signifies the Spirit and regeneration.

verses.text: But a man dies and is laid low; a person breathes his last, and where is he?
verses.comment: In contrast to nature, human death seems final. The question 'where is he?' points to the mystery of the afterlife, a theme more fully revealed later in Scripture.

verses.text: As waters recede from the sea, and a river dries up,
verses.comment: Job compares human death to the drying rivers, reinforcing the theme of inevitable human mortality.

verses.text: so man lies down and does not rise; till the heavens are no more, people will not awake or be roused from their sleep.
verses.comment: Sleep as a metaphor for death anticipates later biblical teaching of resurrection (John 5:28–29). Here, Job expresses an early conception of death as final, yet this leaves the door open for God’s future promise.

verses.text: Oh, that you would hide me in Sheol, that you would conceal me until your anger passes, that you would set a time and remember me!
verses.comment: Job wishes for shelter in death until God’s anger is spent, hoping for remembrance and perhaps restoration. It reflects the Old Testament view of Sheol and yet hints at the desire for vindication and resurrection.

verses.text: If a man dies, shall he live again? All the days of my service I would wait, till my renewal comes.
verses.comment: Job’s asking whether life after death is possible anticipates resurrection doctrine—see 1 Corinthians 15. Early Jews held limited hope, which is deepened and fulfilled in the New Testament.

verses.text: You would call, and I would answer; you would long for the work of your hands.
verses.comment: Here Job reveals an intimate confidence: God desires his creation. This aligns with Christian hope that God personally seeks relationship with humanity, affirming our dignity.

verses.text: For now you count my steps; you do not watch over my sin.
verses.comment: God’s attentive care to every detail of life is shown, but Job notes God does not focus solely on sin. This foreshadows the mercy available through forgiveness and reconciliation.

verses.text: My transgression is sealed up in a bag, and you cover over my iniquity.
verses.comment: The sealing of sin expresses the hope that sins can be dealt with and covered. This foreshadows God’s work of forgiving and covering sins—later fulfilled through the ministry of reconciliation and sacramental absolution.

verses.text: But as a mountain falls and crumbles, and as a rock is moved from its place—
verses.comment: Mountains falling and rocks being moved symbolize inevitable change and mortality, highlighting the fragile nature of creation apart from God’s sustaining power.

verses.text: as water wears away stones and floods wash away the soil of the earth, so you destroy the hope of man.
verses.comment: Job laments the erosion of hope through suffering and death, paralleling spiritual discouragement by earthly trials. Yet elsewhere in Scripture hope endures by faith.

verses.text: You overpower him forever, and he passes away; you change his countenance and send him away.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty over life and death is affirmed—He transforms and removes people from earthly existence, pointing to the mystery of the soul’s afterlife.

verses.text: His children come to honor, and he does not know it; they are brought low, and he is unaware of them.
verses.comment: The dead are cut off from knowledge of earthly events, emphasizing the finality of death and the importance of hope for communion beyond death.

verses.text: He feels only the pain of his own body, and he mourns only for himself.
verses.comment: Job closes this thought in sorrow for human suffering and isolation, reflecting the profound need for restoration—foreshadowing the hope of bodily resurrection and the promise of eternal life in union with God.
